data.title: The Austin Chronicle
data.meta_description: There are many things we can learn from the animals but lessons in love from talking primates is not one of them.
data.text: Iâm not gonna sugarcoat this: Movies donât have to be this bad. And go ahead, call me a killjoy, say itâs crotchety to hold films geared at kids to some critical standard. Bullshit. Kids deserve better. They deserve to have their imaginations tickled and teased, to have miraculous things projected 10 feet tall â not some guy in a gorilla suit playing wingman to Kevin James at a T.G.I. Fridayâs. Actually, is this geared at kids? Because I canât for the life of me figure how the five screenwriters it took to tap out this crapper thought kids would be interested in watching Jamesâ sad-sack zookeeper Griffin try to woo back his mean, vapid ex-girlfriend (Bibb). Hereâs the bait and switch: Griffin is coached in the ways of seduction by talking animals. (Kids love those, right?) But director Frank Coraci, whose last credit was the TV movie Iâm in Hell (that setupâs way too easy), doesnât seem remotely interested in the tactile wonder of a giraffe or a lion; the animals here, the main attractions at a second-rate New England zoo, serve merely as digitally enhanced mouthpieces for comic banter. Some of the jokes hit â and, considering the voice actors are culled mostly from comedy, Iâd wager they did some in-studio rewrite-riffing (Favreau and Love, as squabbling bears, have a giggling bit about a Canadian Kodiak girlfriend, and Sandler, as some kind of marble-mouthed simian, gets points just for being the most cracked-out). But most of the jokes miss, given the filmâs single, suffocating focus on how to shape Griffin into an alpha-male predator. Screenwriting 101 demands an emotional arc for the protagonist â dark times are required to earn the good times to come, sure â but Zookeeperâs team of scribes have made the crucial misstep of crafting a character utterly devoid of moral strength. And did I mention the cruel lust for revenge-taking? (Cause itâs cool to teach kids that violence, be it physical or emotional, should be met with more violence, right?) But, hey, like I said, thereâs that lure of Real. Live. Animals! Oh, wait: Zookeeperâs most prominent animal character, a gorilla named Bernie, is portrayed by a combination of an animatronic ape and a dude in a suit. And you can tell. (Heâs voiced by Nick Nolte, who I can only surmise was cast because the resemblance of that long-ago mugshot to a real-life gorilla was irresistible.) Look, dumb comedyâs fine if itâs, you know, smart about it. Zookeeperâs just dumb-dumb, and, more criminally, has nothing at all of magic to impart to the kids. They deserve so much more.
